thread.title: Anthony Mundine APPEALS loss against Danny Green
thread.title_full: Anthony Mundine APPEALS loss against Danny Green | Daily Mail Online

author: Daniel Peters For Daily Mail Australia
title: Anthony Mundine APPEALS loss against Danny Green
text:
Anthony Mundine has reportedly lodged an official appeal against his controversial points decision loss to Danny Green in last week's fight in Adelaide .
The firebrand Indigenous boxer filed the appeal on Wednesday, wanting the result of the bout changed to 'no decision' instead.
The preliminary protest was made with the Australian National Boxing Federation, which must agree to hear the appeal, according to the Daily Telegraph .
If the federation agrees, three independent local judges will be locked into three separate rooms with videos of the fight and new scorecards.
Sore loser? Anthony Mundine has lodged an official appeal against his controversial points decision loss to Danny Green (Mundine is pictured after the fight last Friday)
The firebrand indigenous boxer wants the result of the bout changed to 'no decision' instead (Danny Green is pictured celebrating his win last Friday)
Their score counts will determine if Green's win stands or whether the result can be reversed and the fight declared a no decision.
Mundine's reported protest involves the controversial first-round incident when he sent Green reeling towards his corner after the referee had stepped in between the fighters.
He wants to know why the referee ruled a foul against Mundine, yet didn't offer a dazed Green the option of a five-minute break under the rules of boxing.
There are also complaints about the unsigned fight card being circulated on social media.
The much-anticipated fight dissipated into controversy almost as soon as the final bell rang, with another layer being added this week when a ringside doctor revealed he quit during the fight after his recommendation that Green was too concussed to go on was ignored.
If Mundine's appeal is accepted, three independent local judges will be locked into three separate rooms with videos of the fight and new scorecards (Mundine pictured last Friday)
There are complaints about an unsigned fight card being circulated on social media (pictured)
Mundine had been quiet on the controversy on Wednesday, but told the Caravan Conversations podcast earlier this week that he believed he won the fight.
'I know I whipped his a*** again,' Mundine said.
'I whipped his a*** for the second time two-nil, two zero. It ruins the credibility of the sport, judging like this, officiating like this. It dampens a great sport, man.
'I thought I won that fight and it's 2-0 ... I deserved it,' Mundine told Fox Sports.
'But history will tell a different story.
'People know in their hearts ... they know who was the better man.'
Last week's fight was a rematch of their first fight in Sydney in May 2006, which Mundine won by unanimous points decision.
Mundine had been quiet on the controversy on Wednesday, but has since told a number of media outlets that he believed he won the fight
Last week's fight was a rematch of their first fight in Sydney in May 2006, which Mundine won by unanimous points decision
